title: AB 289
content: The people of California enact the following. Article 11 of the Legislative Employee Whistleblower Protection Act (Section 9149.30) allows legislative employees to report ethical violations without fear of retribution. A "legislative employee" is defined as someone currently employed by either house of the Legislature, excluding Members. A "protected disclosure" includes filing a complaint with the Joint Legislative Ethics Committee or the Senate Committee on Legislative Ethics. The Senate and Assembly have committees to address ethical violations by members and employees. An ethics ombudsperson can also receive information about potential violations. "Use of official authority or influence" includes promising benefits or taking personnel actions. A Member of the Legislature or legislative employee cannot use their authority to intimidate or interfere with a legislative employee's right to make a protected disclosure. Violators may face fines up to $10,000 and imprisonment. They can also be sued for damages in a civil action. This rule does not allow disclosure of prohibited information. Legislative employees are protected from reprisal for making disclosures. They can file complaints within one year of any improper acts. Legislative employees are protected from reprisal for making disclosures. A person who engages in acts of reprisal against a legislative employee may face fines and imprisonment. Additionally, they can be held liable in a civil action for damages. In civil actions, if it is proven that protected activity contributed to retaliation against a legislative employee, the burden of proof shifts to the offending party to show the action would have occurred for legitimate reasons. Punitive damages can be awarded for malicious acts, and the injured party is entitled to attorney's fees. Legislative employees can bring civil actions without filing a complaint first. A legislative employee can bring civil actions for damages without filing a complaint first. Supervisors can still take personnel actions if justified by evidence separate from protected disclosures. The term "legislative employee" includes former employees if the complaint is filed within one year of the incident. This article does not limit the rights of legislative employees under other laws. The article allows legislative employees to file civil actions for damages without prior complaint if done within one year of the incident. It does not diminish their rights under other laws. No reimbursement is required for local agencies or school districts due to the act creating new crimes or infractions.
